metadata.title: Analysis of the Humoral Immune Response in Vitro to Transmissible Gastroenteritis Virus

abstract.text: Transmissible gastroenteritis virus (TGEV) is a coronavirus that produces a lifethreatening diarrhea in one-to two-week-old pigs but usually results in a transient disease in older swine. The sequence of events resulting from stimulation of gutassociated lymphoid tissue (GALT) leading to production of colostral IgA antibody and ultimately to passive protection of piglets is an active area of TGEV research.' Although antibody production by cultured lymphoid cells has been reported frequently, few studies have focused on in vitro stimulation with specific viral immunogens?-' As a corollary to in vivo studies, we report herein secondary in vitro immunization, with TGEV, of lymphocytes obtained from mesenteric lymph nodes (MLN), a GALT component, and the spleen of swine previously infected with TGEV. This is the first study in which swine lymphocytes have been immunized in vitro with viral antigens.

Weanling pigs (1 5-20 kg) that were seronegative for TGEV-neutralizing antibodies were inoculated with virulent TGEV (Miller strain) by the intranasal-oral route. No sooner than three weeks after the initial inoculation, spleens and MLN's were removed and single cell suspensions were prepared. Duplicate 24-well culture plates (lo' cells/ml/well) were immunized with various concentrations of TGEV; control cultures consisted of primed lymphoid cells that were not inoculated with TGEV. At selected intervals, culture supernatants were removed, dialyzed against PBS and concentrated approximately 40-fold. Initially, the relative immunogenicity of TGEV purified by the method of Brian et aL6 was compared to supernatant fluids of TGEV-infected cells. Lymphocytes obtained from spleens of TGEV-primed pigs were incubated with 0.2 to 5 pg of purified TGEV protein per ten million spleen cells. Culture medium was replaced without additional virus on days 3,7,11, and 14. Primed spleen lymphocytes incubated with culture medium only constituted the experimental controls. Anti-TGEV activity, as measured by RIA and PRNT, was maximal on day 11 and declined on day 14. Purified TGEV protein was superior to crude virus preparations in consistently inducing specific anti-viral antibodies in vitro.

Next, the responsiveness of lymphocytes derived from the MLN's and spleen was compared. Stimulation indices (FIG. 1) response of MLN-derived lymphocytes, as shown by stimulation indices of the RIA, indicated that little antibody was produced by day four, after which virus-specific antibody production increased through day 14 when stimulated with 0.5 and 5 pg TGEV antigen. Neutralizing antibodies were detected as early as day four in stimulated cultures whereas neutralizing titers in control cultures were negligible (titers < 20). Immunodiffusion data suggested the sequential development of IgM, in supernatants obtained on days four and seven, and the simultaneous appearance of IgG and IgA in splenic and MLN-derived lymphocytes on days 7, 11, and 14. Qualitatively, splenic and MLN-derived lymphocytes were equally responsive to secondary in vitro immunization in the synthesis of all antibody classes. We next wished to quantitate the IgA produced in vitro. Culture supernatants of lymphocytes immunized with 0.5 pg TGEV protein were fractionated by HPLC size exclusion and the location of the IgA dimer was determined by RIA using '*'I-labeled goat anti-porcine IgA. The IgA fraction of the MLN-derived lymphocyte cultures neutralized TGEV to higher titers than the same fraction obtained from splenic cultures.In this report we describe the conditions whereby porcine immunoglobulins are produced in lymphoid cell cultures secondarily immunized with TGEV. In general, MLN-derived lymphocytes were superior to splenic lymphocytes in the production of IgGand IgA-neutralizing antibodies. Assessment of the immune response in virro may be adapted to (1) evaluating the interaction of suppressor and helper T lymphocytes and macrophages as mediators of the immune response and (2) screening microgram quantities of TGEV immunogenic subunits and adjuvants to maximize the immune response before extensive livestock trials.
